Message.Title: Bank of America 4th-Quarter Net Plunges 63% on Charges, Lower Revenue
Message.Msg: Bank of America Corp.'s ( BAC ) fourth-quarter profit plunged 63% as the banking giant was weighed down by billions in charges related to a dispute with Fannie Mae ( FNMA ) and a foreclosure settlement, while revenue also tumbled. In settlements announced last week, Bank of America agreed to pay $11.6 billion to Fannie Mae tied to so-called putbacks, the loans that Fannie demands lenders buy back as a result of questionable underwriting and other missteps. The agreement covers nearly a decade of home loans and is the bank's latest response to the hangover from its 2008 acquisition of Countrywide Financial Corp., which was the largest U.S. lender to customers with spotty credit histories. The bank said it would take a $2.7 billion pre-tax charge in the fourth quarter related to the deal. Separately, Bank of America also said the fourth quarter would include $2.5 billion in pretax charges tied to foreclosure reviews, litigation that is primarily mortgage-related, and other mortgage-related matters. Bank of America was part of a group of 10 banks that last week said they would pay $8.5 billion to close a regulatory probe and end a process set up in 2011 amid public outrage over banks' foreclosure practices. Swamped with foreclosure filings, many banks allegedly used "robo-signers" to sign off on thousands of cases, stating falsely that they personally reviewed each one. Still, Chief Executive Brian Moynihan said Thursday that the bank has entered 2013 "strong and well positioned for further growth," highlighting "double-digit growth since last year in mortgage production, commercial lending, and Global Markets revenue." Overall, Bank of America reported a profit of $732 million versus a profit of $1.99 billion a year earlier. On a per- share basis, which includes the payment of preferred dividends, the bank reported earnings of three cents versus 15 cents a year earlier. The most recent period included a per-share impact of 16 cents from the Fannie Mae settlement, a six cent impact from the foreclosure review and litigation expense of five cents a share, among other items. Revenue dropped 25% to $18.66 billion as noninterest income fell 41%. Excluding $700 million of debit valuation and fair value option adjustments, revenue was $19.6 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected per-share earnings of two cents on revenue of $21.03 billion. Credit-loss provisions were $2.2 billion, compared with $2.93 billion a year earlier and $1.77 billion in the third quarter. The net charge-off rate was 1.4%, compared with 1.74% a year earlier and 1.86% in the prior quarter. Bank of America last week said it would sell mortgage-servicing rights on 2 million home loans totaling $306 billion in unpaid principal balance. Lately, the nation's fourth-biggest U.S. mortgage lender is aiming to sell more mortgages through its 5,000-plus branches, a new push in a business it once sought to dominate. Shares were flat at $11.78 in recent premarket trading. Through Wednesday's close, the stock has climbed 82% in the past 12 months.

Message.Title: Bank of America profit fell 63%
Message.Msg: Bank of America profit fell 63% By Hugh Son, Updated: Thursday, January 17, 5:49 AM Jan. 17 (Bloomberg) -- Bank of America Corp. reported profit dropped 63 percent as costs mounted from faulty foreclosures and flawed home loans made as long as a decade ago. Net income dropped in the fourth quarter to $732 million, or 3 cents a diluted share, from $1.99 billion, or 15 cents, a year earlier, according to a statement today from the Charlotte, North Carolina-based company. Adjusted for one-time items, profit was 29 cents a share, beating the 20-cent estimate of 18 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. Chief Executive Officer Brian T. Moynihan has spent his first three years cleaning up after his predecessorâs takeover of Countrywide Financial Corp. and Merrill Lynch & Co., selling more than $60 billion of assets in the process. The bank announced an $11.7 billion deal to end disputes with Fannie Mae on bad home loans this month and joined an $8.5 billion industry accord to compensate for abusive foreclosures. Last year âwas about resolving as many issues as they could,â said Marty Mosby, an analyst at Guggenheim Securities LLC, which manages more than $100 billion, including Bank of America stock. âWhile theyâve had to absorb some losses, they were less than the worst case, and that signifies progress.â Bank of America, ranked second by assets among U.S. lenders, has booked almost $50 billion in costs since 2007 including refunds and litigation tied to defective mortgages and improper foreclosures. In September, Moynihan agreed to pay $2.4 billion to investors who said management hid the extent of Merrill Lynch losses ahead of its 2009 acquisition. Fannie Mae The lender said Jan. 7 it was posting more than $5 billion in pretax fourth-quarter charges to cover the Fannie Mae payments, the foreclosure settlement and mortgage litigation. Results were also skewed by accounting charges tied to changes in the value of the firmâs debt and

Therefore, they have earnings of $3 (in 2-3 years) X P/E of 12 = $36 stock price in Dec/2014 or Dec/2015.

Head Start is an $8 billion per year federal preschool program, designed to improve the kindergarten readiness of low-income children. Message.Title: BAC getting their act together!!
Message.Msg: People are dissappointed with the quarterly report, they just can't see how this company is improving itself. BAC is taking care of another company's #$%$ (Countrywide). I believe this is an honorable thing to do as they could have just put Countrywide into bankruptcy. Let's just focus on 2012 though. BAC has now taken care of all of Countrywide's responsiblity with Fannie Mae from before BAC purchased the company-this is great news. Now we still have Freddie Mac and other Private Lenders to work with. Let's say that to tak care of all the remaining liability surrounding mortgages the eventual cost will be between $20-35 billion which is not chump change. I believe BAC still has $10 billion set aside as before they had about $22 billion set aside for Fannie & Freddie liability. BAC reduced their outstanding debt by just over $96 Billion during 2012. Even if all $96 billion was being charged a paultry 2% the company will be saving about $2 billion in interest alone each yr and it is probably twice that amount easily. BAC makes very good money and by 2014 most of the mortgage related issues will be behind it and they are leading all other banks in Basel 3 assets. By April we should have some news of a buyback or increase in dividend or both. BAC may go lower due to debt ceiling fight but the fundamentals are improving so it will not be down long.

Message.Msg: can't post link but you can find the article on the internet, Weisel was one of the pioneers of financing for the technology and life sciences industries in Silicon Valley, serving as a lifeline to Wall Street at a time when major New York investment banks paid little mind to the sector. He co-founded one of the original West Coast boutique investment banks that catered to such companies, Robertson, Coleman, Siebel & Weisel, and broke off to form his own firm, Montgomery Securities, in 1978. Montgomery was a top underwriter and adviser to hundreds of high-growth companies, including Amgen Inc., AMGN -0.45% E*Trade Group Inc. ETFC +0.10% and Nextel Communications, and helped guide the initial public offering of Web search engine Yahoo YHOO +0.30% in 1996. Montgomery was sold to NationsBank BAC -4.24% for $1.3 billion in 1997, which itself morphed into Bank of America Corp. after a merger the following year.

Message.Msg: ROTFLMAO true enough, liberty, but that's just a symptom and not the root cause of kilgares' rhetorical miscarriages. Want a hint? From what he posted above, it's impossible to tell whether the situation he describes is real or hypothetical, or whether BAC is even in that position. Moving right along, he blithely states that "it is not cool to experience this", as if he's personally had that dubious pleasure. Now consider this: upon hearing that a company's legal fees per share exceeded its earnings per share, a normal person might question its business plan, or its legal strategy, or whether its own lawyers were taking it for a ride. For kilgares, though, there's no need to question anything. He makes the same knee-jerk leap to the same unfounded conclusion he has for every issue or problem that arises, or that he invents: democraps are to blame. Look, I might as well just spell it out for you, liberty: kilgares is one irrational, paranoid, P.O.'d dude, mired in a self-pitying pique even as he swings from aberrant outbursts to delusions of grandeur. To wit: You asked me where I was by kilgares â¢ 8 hours ago I was in Ft. Myers, Florida the other day and I saw a bumper sticker on a parked car that read, "I miss Chicago." So, I broke the window, stole the radio, shot out two of the tires and left a note that read, "I hope this helps!" To fully appreciate the scope of his derangement, though, you'll need to crack open his message history (and ideally a bottle of Woodford's Reserve) and wade through both. Besides claiming that he is "a man of color" and "in line for a high-powered GOP consulting position with the new Romney administration", kilgares constantly employs the Royal "we" ("we are expected to remain silent") in a feeble attempt to drag others into his personal asylum. Message.Title: Low-information liberals are pretty much like this...
Message.Msg: A woman in a hot air balloon realized she was lost. She lowered her altitude and spotted a man in a boat below. She shouted to him, "Excuse me, can you help me? I promised a friend I would meet him an hour ago, but I don't know where I am." The man consulted his portable GPS and replied, "You're in a hot air balloon, approximately 30 feet above ground elevation of 2,346 feet above sea level. You are at 31 degrees, 14.97 minutes north latitude and 100 degrees, 49.09 minutes west longitude. She rolled her eyes and said, "You must be a Republican. "I am," replied the man. "How did you know?" "Well," answered the balloonist, "everything you told me is technically correct. But I have no idea what to do with your information, and I'm still lost. Frankly, you've not been much help to me." The man smiled and responded, "You must be an Obama-Democrat." "I am," replied the balloonist. "How did you know?" "Well," said the man, "You don't know where you are -- or where you are going. You've risen to where you are due to a large quantity of hot air. You made a promise you have no idea how to keep, and you expect me to solve your problem. You're in exactly the same position you were in before we met, but somehow, now it's MY fault."
